Suspected Pneumonia.Risk Factors: Exposure to pathogens (e.g., in community, hospitals, or through travel); Smoking and chronic lung diseases (COPD, asthma);OSA; Immunosuppressive conditions (HIV/AIDS, use of immunosuppressive drugs); Elderly age; Comorbidities (diabetes, heart disease); etc.
Suspected Pneumonia.Symptoms: Typical: Cough (dry or productive of sputum), fever, chills, dyspnea (shortness of breath), Less typical: Chest pain, headache, fatigue, myalgia (muscle pain).; etc.
Suspected Pneumonia.Signs: Crackles and/or wheezing on lung auscultation; tachypnea (increased respiratory rate); fever; cyanosis (bluish skin color due to lack of oxygen). ;Hypotension; tachycardia (increased heart rate); altered mental status in severe cases.; etc.

knowledge.Pneumonia:
Radiological examination: Chest X-rays or CT scans are the most commonly used methods and can show areas of inflammation in the lungs. On X-ray or CT images, inflammation appears as localized shadows or infiltrative lesions.
;Microbiological tests: Identification of the causative pathogen can be confirmed through microbial cultures and PCR tests of body fluids such as sputum, blood, or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.
;Complete blood count (CBC): An increased white blood cell count in the CBC is commonly associated with infection but is not a specific indicator.
;Blood gas analysis: For patients with severe pneumonia, blood gas analysis can help assess oxygenation and acid-base balance.
;C-reactive protein and other inflammatory markers: Levels of these markers typically rise during infections, but they also lack specificity.
knowledge.Bacterial Pneumonia: Detection of specific bacteria by PCR or other molecular biology methods. Or suppuration caused by bacteria
knowledge.Viral Pneumonia: PCR technology detects the genetic material of a specific virus
